firstTime.scenario: Yo, I got this beautiful piece of halibut with lemon and capers. Keep it simple, let the fish do the talking, you know what I'm saying?

option1Wine.feedbackText: Nah, nah... halibut's too delicate for red wine, my friend.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Yo, that's what I'm talking about! You let the fish shine with the right wine.

option3Wine.feedbackText: Close, but white wine's cleaner profile is what this delicate fish needs.

firstTime.scenario: I'm working on some braised short ribs that been cooking all day. Fall-off-the-bone tender, rich as anything.

option1Wine.feedbackText: Now that's what I call understanding! Rich meat needs rich wine.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Come on now, short ribs that rich need red wine's full body and tannins.

option3Wine.feedbackText: Rosé's nice, but this dish needs the power that only red wine can bring.

firstTime.scenario: I got this nice piece of swordfish, grilled with herbs and olive oil. Meaty fish, but still fish, you feel me?

option1Wine.feedbackText: Even though swordfish is meaty, it's still fish—white wine's the way to go.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Exactly! You get that even meaty fish still needs white wine's touch.

option3Wine.feedbackText: Good thinking with the middle ground, but white wine's the classic choice here.

remedial.scenario: I'm doing it old school—spaghetti with clam sauce, garlic, and white wine. Classic Italian-American, baby.

option1Wine.feedbackText: Come on, clam sauce calls for white wine—it's right there in the dish!

option2Wine.feedbackText: Perfect! White wine echoes the sauce and complements those clams.

remedial.scenario: Tonight I'm smoking some brisket low and slow. Bark's looking good, meat's gonna be butter.

option1Wine.feedbackText: Yes! Red wine's bold character matches that smoked brisket perfectly.

option2Wine.feedbackText: Smoked brisket needs red wine's intensity to match all that flavor, know what I'm saying?
